llm_processed_output.source_summary: This document metadata describes an article titled "Sementes do Messias : percursos do messianismo régio ibérico (sécs. XIV-XVI)" by Jacqueline Hermann, published in 2015. The article discusses the routes of royal messianism in the Iberian world between the 14th and 16th centuries. It explores the roots of royal messianism in Iberia from the Middle Ages and its developments in the Modern Period. A key element connecting it to the historical topic is the reference to the defeat of the Portuguese by the Moors in Alcácer Quibir, as a context for the rise of Portuguese Sebastianism, which is the best example of royal messianic expectations. Although it doesn't directly address the battle of Al-'Uqab (معركة العقاب), it mentions a defeat by the Moors that created a particular political context, suggesting a potentially relevant broader historical context.
extracted_key_facts: The article title is "Sementes do Messias : percursos do messianismo régio ibérico (sécs. XIV-XVI)".
The author is Jacqueline Hermann from the Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro.
The article was published in 2015 in Mirabilia, Núm. 21 (Jun-Dez 2015), p. 222-241.
The article discusses royal messianism in the Iberian world between the 14th and 16th centuries.
It identifies roots of royal messianism in Iberia from the Middle Ages.
The article mentions the defeat of the Portuguese by the Moors in Alcácer Quibir as a factor contributing to Portuguese Sebastianism.
The subjects covered include Iberian peninsula, Judaism, Messianism, and Sebastianism.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: The article by Azz al-Din Jassus discusses the military strategy of the Almohads in the western Mediterranean. It argues that the Almohads expanded eastward, opening a front with Arab tribes in Africa and the Banu Ghaniya in the Balearic Islands. However, their focus on the eastern front led to neglecting the more dangerous northern front in al-Andalus. This strategic misdirection, according to the article, contributed to the Almohad defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa (معركة العقاب), which had disastrous consequences for al-Andalus and Morocco. The article further states that the Christian Reconquista took advantage of the Almohad weakness, seizing the Balearic Islands and major cities such as Cordoba, Valencia, Murcia, Jaen, and Seville. It concludes that the Almohads lacked a balanced geo-political view, failing to recognize the greater threat coming from the north.
extracted_key_facts: The Almohads expanded their state eastward, creating a front with Arab tribes in Africa and the Banu Ghaniya of the Balearic Islands.
The Almohads focused their military efforts on the eastern front, neglecting the northern front in al-Andalus.
The Almohad strategy in the western Mediterranean was flawed, as revealed by their defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa (معركة العقاب).
The Almohad defeat at the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa had catastrophic consequences for al-Andalus and Morocco.
Following the Almohad defeat, the Christian Reconquista seized the Balearic Islands.
During the Almohad period, major cities like Cordoba, Valencia, Murcia, Jaen, and Seville fell to the Christians.
The Almohads lacked a balanced geo-political view, failing to recognize the threat from the north (Christian kingdoms).
The article is authored by Azz al-Din Jassus.
The article was published in June 2015, Volume 1, Issue 2 of the 'Astour' journal for historical studies.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: The provided text is a chapter from the book "Relaciones políticas y guerra : la experiencia castellano-leonesa frente al Islam : siglos XI-XIII" by Francisco García Fitz, published by Universidad de Sevilla in 2015. Specifically, it is the chapter titled "La política castellano-leonesa frente al imperio almohade" (Castilian-Leonese politics in the face of the Almohad empire), covering pages 109-158. Other chapters in the same volume include topics such as political strategy, relations, and the beginnings of a political strategy of dissolution under Fernando I and Alfonso VI; the strategy against the Almoravids and the second Taifas during Alfonso VII's reign; political relations in the era of the third Taifas; and the march towards the battle of the Strait. The resource appears to be relevant because the Almohad Empire was a key player in the context of the battle of Las Navas de Tolosa/معركة العقاب.
